intro: Daniellia caudata, commonly known as the African wild date, is a tropical tree native to Central and East Africa. It belongs to the family Euphorbiaceae and is characterized by its smooth, grey bark and large, palmately lobed leaves. The plant produces small, greenish-yellow flowers followed by woody, spiny capsules containing edible seeds. It thrives in moist, fertile soils and is often found in lowland rainforests. Due to its unique appearance and ecological importance, it is a valuable species in both traditional medicine and local ecosystems.
